summary: The U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina today entered a final judgment against S&R Grandview, LLC, a North Carolina limited liability company, for violating the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Pender County, North Carolina, alleges that, in 2005, Frieze, Ganer, and another manager of the company, Steven Silverman, violated Rule 41(a)(1) by failing to timely respond to requests for an emergency court order granting a temporary restraining order against Ganer and Silverman from violating the two-dismissal rule. The complaint further alleges that in 2011, after acquiring a second loan from Gramercy Warehouse Funding II LLC (Gramercy), Frieze and Ganer entered into an agreement to purchase and resell Lot 33R in the amount of $306,000, which was the amount due under the second loan. The SEC alleges that on or about 17 November 2006, the defendants filed a second complaint alleging that Ganer had breached the securities registration provisions of Rule 41, and that he was the only authorized manager of Defendant. On the same day, the trial court entered an order granting Ganer a temporary injunction, freezing the assets of the defendants, and ordering Ganer to pay a civil penalty of $368,113. The court also granted Ganer the right to reapply as a defendant in the future.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for North Carolina announced criminal charges against Frieze.  According to the SEC's Complaint, filed on April 5, 2017, the SEC obtained an emergency order granting the defendants a temporary injunctive relief order, ordering Frieze to comply with the court order, and appointing a receiver to oversee the sale of the real estate. The receiver also agreed to pay disgorgement and prejudgment interest of $1,038,067, and to be barred from serving as an officer or director of a public company for five years.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, the receiver has consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins him from future violations of the federal securities laws, orders him to pay civil penalties of $192,768, and bars him from participating in the issuance, purchase, sale, or sale of any real estate, and from providing or providing any other assistance to the receiver in the case. The settlement is subject to court approval.  On June 13, 2018, the court granted the defendants' motion for a preliminary injunction and ordered Ganer
